description: Excel 2016 is the powerful spreadsheet application in the Office suite. It seems every organization, large and small, uses Excel to organize and analyze data. However, many users are intimidated by Excel and confused by how it behaves as an application. The Excel 2016 Essentials series strives to empower users by learning the foundations to conquer this program. We begin with basic skills such as navigating the interface, identifying items in a spreadsheet, selecting cells, and inputting data. The series also covers formatting text and numbers, modifying a worksheet layout, printing and page layout, and managing worksheets in a workbook. While this series is designed for beginner users, it has lots of great tips and tricks for experienced users as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne kick off the Microsoft Excel 2016 Essentials series. They define  a spreadsheet, discuss the history of Excel and file types, and introduce other foundational concepts for this course.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne cover the basics of working with Excel in Windows operating system. They review foundational skills and items such as starting Excel, the title bar, minimize and maximize, full screen mode, create a blank workbook, open an existing workbook, save vs. save as, and keyboard shortcuts.
episodes.title: Excel Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the multiple ways that you can select and work with cells in Excel. They demonstrate  click/hold/drag, deselecting, range selecting, selecting with shift and arrow keys, select all, select multiple worksheets, select text in multiple worksheets, named ranges, and how to use find and replace.
episodes.title: Select Cells

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore the variety of ways that you can insert data into your Excel worksheet. Here they cover: entering data into a cell, editing data in a cell, controlling data and cell overflow, autocorrect options, moving data to new cell, copy/paste, and clear cell data.

00:23:24.300 --> 00:23:28.480
range of cells, you just hit the Escape
key and the running ants will go away.

I had people in class like, I don't know,

00:23:32.225 --> 00:23:33.870

>> I'm like, it's okay,

Those are like, okay, I'm done,

I know Excel like the back of my hand.

I'm like, but it's only 9:30,

Now, if I can insert information

I also wanted to talk about deleting

00:24:15.136 --> 00:24:21.180
not the backspace key but delete, and then

483
00:24:21.180 --> 00:24:22.900
All right, simple enough.

484
00:24:22.900 --> 00:24:24.410
Let's try this one.

485
00:24:24.410 --> 00:24:25.760
Select this, same thing.

00:24:26.940 --> 00:24:29.379
There's my delete and

00:24:33.150 --> 00:24:37.636

it's typing it is as $8.00.

00:24:41.530 --> 00:24:42.832

00:24:42.832 --> 00:24:48.371

the styles, everything is being retained,

00:24:48.371 --> 00:24:52.724
so when you're deleting by using

you're only deleting the contents and

They're like I,
it will not stop typing in $8.00.

00:25:03.360 --> 00:25:07.160
I want it to just say 8, that's it.

497
00:25:07.160 --> 00:25:08.500
You gotta get rid of the formats.

498
00:25:08.500 --> 00:25:09.836

499
00:25:09.836 --> 00:25:11.959
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

[LAUGH]

00:25:17.093 --> 00:25:17.992
You don't have to do that.

00:25:17.992 --> 00:25:22.340

A to get everything selected.

00:25:22.340 --> 00:25:26.226
I want not just the contents,
I want everything to go away.

00:25:29.930 --> 00:25:33.540
Delete everything in cell or just

00:25:33.540 --> 00:25:34.570

510
00:25:34.570 --> 00:25:36.280
You get to pick.

511
00:25:36.280 --> 00:25:38.368
So I could, this is another one.

512
00:25:38.368 --> 00:25:42.086
I could keep all the contents,
but just take out the formats and

00:25:42.086 --> 00:25:43.950

514
00:25:43.950 --> 00:25:48.132
It's all still there, it's just it's
like removed formatting in Word.

515
00:25:48.132 --> 00:25:50.289
>> Yeah.
>> It's fantastic if it's like I don't

00:25:50.289 --> 00:25:52.474
like the way it came in, I wanna redo it.

00:25:52.474 --> 00:25:56.746
But if I wanted to really get
rid of all of these contents,

518
00:25:56.746 --> 00:26:00.671
like get rid of everything,
you go to the clear all.

519
00:26:00.671 --> 00:26:03.190
When I clear all, okay.

520
00:26:03.190 --> 00:26:07.090
Now if I type in this it will be 8 and
it's not $8.00 anymore,

521
00:26:07.090 --> 00:26:09.980
because I removed the contents and
the formats.

522
00:26:09.980 --> 00:26:13.302
So that's kind of a big
thing to know about.

523
00:26:13.302 --> 00:26:16.360
Again, one of those small things that it
makes all the difference in the world.

524
00:26:17.840 --> 00:26:19.676
One last thing about copying and pasting.

00:26:19.676 --> 00:26:23.080
Because we're copying and pasting from
Excel and talked about all the different

paste options with like the values,

don't keep the number formats,
source, the blah, blah, blah.

528
00:26:28.605 --> 00:26:29.469
Blah, blah, blah.

529
00:26:29.469 --> 00:26:30.206
Blah, blah, blah.

530

[LAUGH] Copying from Word.

531
00:26:33.268 --> 00:26:37.940
Yeah, well, remember, Word and Excel are

00:26:37.940 --> 00:26:39.960

Vonne.

533
00:26:39.960 --> 00:26:42.408
So they've got to work so
well with each other.

534
00:26:42.408 --> 00:26:43.920
>> Well,
they actually do a pretty good job.

535
00:26:43.920 --> 00:26:44.937
>> They do do a pretty good job.

So in here, in Word, I have paragraphs.

Every time I hit the Enter key,

00:26:51.410 --> 00:26:52.970
So I have character formatting.

And I do have some of that

I'm gonna select these paragraphs, okay?

I have one, two, three, four, five.

00:27:06.198 --> 00:27:07.480
I have five paragraphs.

00:27:07.480 --> 00:27:08.090
I'm gonna copy.

00:27:08.090 --> 00:27:11.890
I'm gonna do control C, you're just

Come back over here to book one and

00:27:15.810 --> 00:27:19.595
I'm going to click in cell G4.

Just because.

00:27:20.889 --> 00:27:24.790
I did not double click,

Every time there was a paragraph,

00:27:34.430 --> 00:27:39.630

555
00:27:39.630 --> 00:27:40.704
Same thing here.

556
00:27:40.704 --> 00:27:42.566
And I'm so
glad you asked me those questions,

00:27:42.566 --> 00:27:44.830
because it's tying right
into everything I'm doing.

00:27:44.830 --> 00:27:46.170
It's almost like you planned it.

00:27:46.170 --> 00:27:46.800
>> Yeah, but I didn't.

00:27:46.800 --> 00:27:48.120
>> I know, we totally didn't.

00:27:48.120 --> 00:27:49.744

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So here, it went ahead and

And it automatically made the column

00:28:01.770 --> 00:28:02.672
>> I like it.
>> Yeah.

So it does play nicely together.

00:28:04.990 --> 00:28:06.390
And then we have another paragraph.

00:28:06.390 --> 00:28:10.570
So copying from Word into here, it's

Now in Word,

If you come up and select the whole table,

it's already in a column and

If you select that table, copy it,

00:28:33.500 --> 00:28:36.840
I'm just gonna scroll down into

00:28:36.840 --> 00:28:37.980
Hit the paste button.

00:28:37.980 --> 00:28:40.920
It's gonna go ahead and

00:28:40.920 --> 00:28:45.650

00:28:45.650 --> 00:28:48.026
You do have,

If I click that, now it's just text or,

00:29:05.846 --> 00:29:08.760

00:29:08.760 --> 00:29:09.730

If I have tabular information in Word,

It just looked at it as like,

00:29:38.321 --> 00:29:40.300
It did a word wrap for me automatically.

00:29:45.597 --> 00:29:48.200
And don't activate the flashing cursor.

Double click, flashing cursor, paste.

It all goes into that one cell.

00:30:08.381 --> 00:30:10.400

00:30:10.400 --> 00:30:11.950

A single click versus
a double click in a cell, but

606
00:30:15.400 --> 00:30:19.754
it does do a pretty vast difference

607
00:30:19.754 --> 00:30:23.303

pasting from Word.

608
00:30:23.303 --> 00:30:26.990
And like I said, from websites, just-

>> It's probably gonna to be a lot easier

00:30:35.758 --> 00:30:38.467

613
00:30:38.467 --> 00:30:41.180
>> Yeah, that's a whole show unto itself,
right Vonne?

614
00:30:41.180 --> 00:30:42.155
>> It sure is.

615
00:30:42.155 --> 00:30:43.463
[LAUGH]
>> All right.

616
00:30:43.463 --> 00:30:48.550
Well Vonne, very interesting today with
looking at how we get data into the cells,

617
00:30:48.550 --> 00:30:50.320
how we can manipulate them,
play with that stuff.

618
00:30:50.320 --> 00:30:51.190
Very, very cool stuff.

619
00:30:51.190 --> 00:30:53.430
There's many different ways
in which we can do that.

620
00:30:53.430 --> 00:30:55.010
So I know I learned today.

621
00:30:55.010 --> 00:30:56.420
Hopefully you guys learned a lot.

622
00:30:56.420 --> 00:30:58.286
I had my mind just [SOUND].

623
00:30:58.286 --> 00:30:59.527
I should have worn a helmet.

624
00:30:59.527 --> 00:31:00.965
It was so awesome.

625
00:31:00.965 --> 00:31:04.035
And Vonne, you are an awesome teacher,
we do thank you for spending your time and

626
00:31:04.035 --> 00:31:07.415
effort on us, so
that we might be as cool as you one day.

627
00:31:07.415 --> 00:31:10.045
That being said, it looks like we
are out of time for this episode,

628
00:31:10.045 --> 00:31:12.395
we do thank you folks out there for
watching.

629
00:31:12.395 --> 00:31:15.155
Signing off for Office Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

630
00:31:15.155 --> 00:31:16.145
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

631
00:31:16.145 --> 00:31:18.189
>> We'll see you next time.

632
00:31:18.189 --> 00:31:28.010
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore how to fill series  data and use the flash fill functions of Microsoft Excel 2016. These features expand the way you copy and paste data and will predict ranges like dates and common item lists.
episodes.title: Fill Series and Flash Fill

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne go through the common file types supported by Excel 2016. Here they explain .xlsx files, Comma Separated Value(.csv) files, OpenDocument Spreadsheet(.ods) files, and Excel Templates(.xltx) files.
episodes.title: Export and File Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore modifying a worksheet in Excel 2016. They demonstrate how to select columns and rows, change column height and row width, insert and delete rows/columns, hide columns and rows, merge cells, and apply word wrap to cells.
episodes.title: Modify a Worksheet

episodes.description:
"
In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show how to format a worksheet in Excel 2016. Here they talk about selecting fonts, adding borders and shading, and copying formats with the format painter. "
episodes.title: Format a Worksheet

00:18:06.723 --> 00:18:10.299
This is like USF colors,
that's where I went to school.

366
00:18:10.299 --> 00:18:10.946
Go Bulls.

367
00:18:10.946 --> 00:18:13.830
And then we're gonna take that,
it was a little bit darker of a green.

368
00:18:13.830 --> 00:18:18.321
So I've got that, and
we'll make it Arial Black.

369
00:18:18.321 --> 00:18:22.080
This is formatting on
this particular cell.

370
00:18:22.080 --> 00:18:26.200
I want this to be copied over to,
say, this cell and this cell and

371
00:18:26.200 --> 00:18:29.720
some other cells in there,
the formats, not the contents.

372
00:18:29.720 --> 00:18:32.200
We're not doing Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V.

373
00:18:32.200 --> 00:18:35.010
What we can do is use,
let's call it the Format Painter.

374
00:18:35.010 --> 00:18:37.900
The Format Painter paints formats.

375
00:18:37.900 --> 00:18:42.044
And it's just like painting a house and
you have a can of paint, right?

376
00:18:42.044 --> 00:18:44.839
You take the brush, and
you dip the brush into the can,

377
00:18:44.839 --> 00:18:46.560
And then you come over here and
you paint on the walls.

378
00:18:46.560 --> 00:18:48.615
So whatever's in the can gets
put on the walls, right?

379
00:18:48.615 --> 00:18:49.388
>> Mm-hm.
>> Or at least that's,

380
00:18:49.388 --> 00:18:50.444
I guess that's-
>> That's the idea.

381
00:18:50.444 --> 00:18:51.050
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH] Or

382
00:18:51.050 --> 00:18:54.820
I mean don't kick the can over or
it's gonna spill everywhere.

383
00:18:54.820 --> 00:18:55.874
I've never done that.

384
00:18:55.874 --> 00:18:58.380
>> Stepped in the roller thing one time.

385
00:18:58.380 --> 00:19:00.320
I was walking around like what's going on.

386
00:19:00.320 --> 00:19:01.380
>> Yeah.

387
00:19:01.380 --> 00:19:02.908
>> Little footprints all over the place.

388
00:19:02.908 --> 00:19:03.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> That was awesome.

389
00:19:03.940 --> 00:19:04.990
>> I've done that one too.

390
00:19:04.990 --> 00:19:05.891
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> So

391
00:19:05.891 --> 00:19:08.079
i actually did knock over
the entire paint can.

392
00:19:08.079 --> 00:19:09.296
>> That's right.

393
00:19:09.296 --> 00:19:11.528
>> [SOUND] It was like,
that was not a good time.

394
00:19:11.528 --> 00:19:18.762
So I've got here,it's the same idea
to where I have the paint can here.

395
00:19:18.762 --> 00:19:22.660
I've got a brush up here and
so you select the cell.

396
00:19:22.660 --> 00:19:25.110
And the nice thing is
you have your list here.

397
00:19:25.110 --> 00:19:28.736
Select the content, the format you like,
click the Format Painter.

398
00:19:28.736 --> 00:19:31.530
If I single-click it, look at my cursor,

399
00:19:31.530 --> 00:19:36.620
looks like a little paintbrush, and
then I select the cell that I want!

400
00:19:38.420 --> 00:19:40.648
Just like that, we just talked about.

401
00:19:40.648 --> 00:19:43.618
But what about those spray guns, you know.

402
00:19:43.618 --> 00:19:47.696
>> Yes.
>> I've never gotten the privilege, yes-

403
00:19:47.696 --> 00:19:48.303
>> They're great.

404
00:19:48.303 --> 00:19:49.580
They're called airless sprayers.

405
00:19:49.580 --> 00:19:50.633
I used to be a painter.

406
00:19:50.633 --> 00:19:51.713
Okay, so you know about this.

407
00:19:51.713 --> 00:19:52.243
>> I've worked with them, yes.

408
00:19:52.243 --> 00:19:52.933
>> Yeah.

409
00:19:52.933 --> 00:19:56.777
Well this is the real world
example I always give.

410
00:19:56.777 --> 00:19:59.080
You just turn the gun on,
it just goes, right?

411
00:19:59.080 --> 00:20:02.450
So that's the whole idea here,
is like I was just a one time thing.

412
00:20:02.450 --> 00:20:07.270
If I want to say, take this particular
formatting and paint it everywhere,

413
00:20:07.270 --> 00:20:11.388
You double click the Format Painter and
then you've got that spray gun, basically.

414
00:20:11.388 --> 00:20:14.220
So if I double click,
I've kind of activated it and

415
00:20:14.220 --> 00:20:19.225
then I can click here, and
I can click here, and here, and here.

416
00:20:19.225 --> 00:20:22.710
But if it probably like something I would
do, I'd be like, gosh, here I'm going,

417
00:20:22.710 --> 00:20:23.891
I'm going crazy, right?

418
00:20:23.891 --> 00:20:27.045
[LAUGH] I'm going all over the place so
you gotta stop the gun.

419
00:20:27.045 --> 00:20:28.142
You gotta turn it off.

420
00:20:28.142 --> 00:20:32.210
So then, when you're done using that
Format Painter, you come up and

421
00:20:32.210 --> 00:20:32.980
just turn it off.

422
00:20:32.980 --> 00:20:37.603
And now, you don't have that initiated,
if you wanna say, or activated.

423
00:20:37.603 --> 00:20:41.299
So, but this is really handy and
the Format Painter is in all of your

424
00:20:41.299 --> 00:20:45.540
products so this works in Word this
works in PowerPoint, it's a lot of fun.

425
00:20:45.540 --> 00:20:47.166
So I really like that.

426
00:20:47.166 --> 00:20:50.710
And then one other one
that I wanted to show you.

427
00:20:50.710 --> 00:20:53.763
>> Let's do our handy-dandy Ctrl+Z.

428
00:20:53.763 --> 00:20:55.232
>> It does work well, doesn't it?

429
00:20:55.232 --> 00:20:55.986
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

430
00:20:55.986 --> 00:20:57.480
It is a beautiful thing.

431
00:20:57.480 --> 00:20:59.240
So, I wanna take this.

432
00:20:59.240 --> 00:21:00.970
You can also use the fill handle.

433
00:21:00.970 --> 00:21:04.170
Cuz we talked about using the fill
handle for filling in series.

434
00:21:04.170 --> 00:21:07.450
And the whole job of that is to copy,
and then we could change that and

435
00:21:07.450 --> 00:21:10.800
change to the weekdays, and
all that kind of fun stuff.

436
00:21:10.800 --> 00:21:14.330
Although same thing can be done for
your Fill in with formats.

437
00:21:14.330 --> 00:21:18.044
So if I take this, get the black
plus sign, our little fill handle.

438
00:21:18.044 --> 00:21:22.076
Click Hold and drag down,
as I I didn't wanna do that.

439
00:21:22.076 --> 00:21:26.360
Now this is that, indicating or activating
that special list that we have here.

440
00:21:27.560 --> 00:21:31.721
Our good old trusty smart tag,
if I click on this smart tag,

441
00:21:31.721 --> 00:21:34.601
I don't wanna fill series,
I don't even wanna copy the cells.

442
00:21:34.601 --> 00:21:37.935
I just wanna fill with formatting only.

443
00:21:37.935 --> 00:21:38.840
That's pretty cool.

444
00:21:38.840 --> 00:21:40.910
So if I click on that, there you go.

445
00:21:40.910 --> 00:21:43.370
So now, it's changing and
just using any format.

446
00:21:43.370 --> 00:21:44.448
And this could be for

447
00:21:44.448 --> 00:21:48.646
number formats as well, because I've
separated that out into two episodes.

448
00:21:48.646 --> 00:21:52.686
But it is a format for your cells,
and so you could go ahead and

449
00:21:52.686 --> 00:21:56.822
use those different ways of
copying that particular format.

450
00:21:56.822 --> 00:21:58.472
Now, I do have more to talk about.

451
00:21:58.472 --> 00:22:00.260
>> Okay.
>> But you are giving me that little

452
00:22:00.260 --> 00:22:01.240
signal of hey,

453
00:22:01.240 --> 00:22:04.460
I think we're gonna, we need to kinda
wrap this particular episode up.

454
00:22:04.460 --> 00:22:06.700
>> Giving it the, let's do it?

455
00:22:06.700 --> 00:22:08.484
>> Yeah.
>> Let's wrap that up now?

456
00:22:08.484 --> 00:22:10.010
>> Come on, let's go.

457
00:22:10.010 --> 00:22:12.671
>> So we'll be back for
some cell alignments and

458
00:22:12.671 --> 00:22:16.812
then we'll talk about styles and
themes, which I love to talk about.

459
00:22:16.812 --> 00:22:18.610
But I'll keep it brief for you.

460
00:22:18.610 --> 00:22:21.060
>> All right, well Vonne, thanks so
much for getting us so far.

461
00:22:21.060 --> 00:22:22.850
We do thank you,
good folks out there for watching.

462
00:22:22.850 --> 00:22:24.686
Definitely come back for the part two.

463
00:22:24.686 --> 00:22:28.446
And see what we can do with all that
lovely bells and whistles that Vonne shows

464
00:22:28.446 --> 00:22:31.350
us how to turn on,
Do cool stuff with our Excel worksheets.

465
00:22:31.350 --> 00:22:33.310
Very cool stuff, thanks Vonne,
so much for that.

466
00:22:33.310 --> 00:22:36.010
We do thank you for watching but
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

467
00:22:36.010 --> 00:22:38.285
For OfficePro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

468
00:22:38.285 --> 00:22:39.300
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

469
00:22:39.300 --> 00:22:43.453
>> And we'll see you next time.

470
00:22:43.453 --> 00:22:46.960
[MUSIC]

episodes.description:
"
Daniel and Vonne continue with formatting a worksheet. In this episode, they cover aligning data in cells, cell styles, and themes."
episodes.title: Format a Worksheet Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.001 --> 00:00:06.214
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.214 --> 00:00:07.962
All right, greetings everyone, and

3
00:00:07.962 --> 00:00:10.539
welcome back to another great
episode of OfficeProTV.

4
00:00:10.539 --> 00:00:13.494
I am your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

5
00:00:13.494 --> 00:00:16.690
we're back with more in our
Excel 2016 Essential series.

6
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:19.060
That just rolls right off the tongue,
it's so much fun to say it.

7
00:00:19.060 --> 00:00:22.737
It's even more fun to be a part of, and
joining us back in the studio to help us

8
00:00:22.737 --> 00:00:25.940
have a lot more fun is our good friend,
Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:26.986
Vonne, we're glad to have you again.

10
00:00:26.986 --> 00:00:28.491
How's it going today, and
what are we gonna learn?

11
00:00:28.491 --> 00:00:31.510
>> [LAUGH] Well, I'm great, one.

12
00:00:31.510 --> 00:00:33.658
Two, this is Part 2.

13
00:00:33.658 --> 00:00:37.985
[LAUGH] So we're continuing on
with formatting our worksheet, and

14
00:00:37.985 --> 00:00:40.930
we had left off with the format painter.

15
00:00:40.930 --> 00:00:45.070
We were talking about how to
use a fill handle, and so

16
00:00:45.070 --> 00:00:48.140
now we're gonna move on to how we're
gonna do some alignments, right?

17
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:50.489
We all need to be in sync and in a line.

18
00:00:50.489 --> 00:00:53.899
So we're going to do our vertical
alignment, diagonal alignment,

19
00:00:53.899 --> 00:00:55.148
horizontal alignment.

20
00:00:55.148 --> 00:00:58.018
And then there's actually something
that I forgot to tell you

21
00:00:58.018 --> 00:01:01.720
about with the cell fills with the
different ways that we can change that.

22
00:01:01.720 --> 00:01:04.719
I'm gonna show you how to do a gradient
one, which is kind of hidden in there.

23
00:01:04.719 --> 00:01:07.710
It doesn't just jump out at
you like it does in Word.

24
00:01:07.710 --> 00:01:09.060
So I'll show where that's it,

25
00:01:09.060 --> 00:01:14.000
because we are going to need to go back
into the Format Cells dialogue box.

26
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:18.998
So I'm actually right where I
left off in the file that we were

27
00:01:18.998 --> 00:01:22.030
working in before in our part uno.

28
00:01:22.030 --> 00:01:23.412
Now we're in part dos.

29
00:01:23.412 --> 00:01:25.549
All right, let's go over to,

30
00:01:25.549 --> 00:01:29.507
why don't we jump over to
a different worksheet for now?

31
00:01:29.507 --> 00:01:32.960
Cuz we talked about our row
hyphen column width there.

32
00:01:32.960 --> 00:01:37.090
Let's just make this row 1 a little
higher, and you can see that the default

33
00:01:37.090 --> 00:01:41.250
alignment of our cells is going
to be on that bottom alignment.

34
00:01:41.250 --> 00:01:45.263
And we did touch on this in
the modifier worksheet episode.

35
00:01:45.263 --> 00:01:49.530
But now we're in the format where
we'll take it to the next level.

36
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:55.050
Up here, let's go ahead, and first of all,
select the cells that we want to format.

37
00:01:55.050 --> 00:01:58.000
Because I could see,
I almost went to go click that button and

38
00:01:58.000 --> 00:02:01.230
realized that like, wait,
back up, where do I need to be?

39
00:02:01.230 --> 00:02:02.320
Select to affect.

40
00:02:02.320 --> 00:02:05.360
So let's take these cells right here, and

41
00:02:05.360 --> 00:02:10.680
change the alignment on the vertical
axis up here on these little buttons.

42
00:02:10.680 --> 00:02:12.610
Do I want it to be top of the line?

43
00:02:12.610 --> 00:02:14.355
Do I want it to be bottom of the line?

44
00:02:14.355 --> 00:02:16.378
But notice if I click off to this,

45
00:02:16.378 --> 00:02:20.085
that it did not change that
line because that's our border.

46
00:02:20.085 --> 00:02:21.358
That's our cell border,

47
00:02:21.358 --> 00:02:25.580
so to wherever the bottom of that cell,
that's where it's going to stay.

48
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:28.483
So that's a little bit different
than if we had underlines, but

49
00:02:28.483 --> 00:02:31.627
then it would also be only the words,
so just kinda clarifying that.

50
00:02:31.627 --> 00:02:36.710
And I like a nice vertical justification
of a middle vertical justification.

51
00:02:36.710 --> 00:02:40.510
Justification and alignment,
they mean the same thing.

52
00:02:40.510 --> 00:02:43.958
So another thing that we could do
if I go ahead and select our cells,

53
00:02:43.958 --> 00:02:47.680
is we could go ahead and do our
horizontal alignment left by default.

54
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:52.073
But if I wanted it to be centered, I can
center the text within each one of those

55
00:02:52.073 --> 00:02:54.451
cells, or I can also make it right align.

56
00:02:54.451 --> 00:02:58.130
I think I'll stick with our
center alignment there, and

57
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:00.610
that looks pretty good.

58
00:03:00.610 --> 00:03:04.150
Some other things you can do
besides just doing vertical and

59
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:07.460
horizontal, you could go diagonal.

60
00:03:07.460 --> 00:03:09.341
And this is something
that I always think of,

61
00:03:09.341 --> 00:03:12.525
I always remember it always equating
back to school, aren't we, Daniel?

62
00:03:12.525 --> 00:03:14.217
We always talk about handwriting?

63
00:03:14.217 --> 00:03:17.357
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, we love to muse on and

64
00:03:17.357 --> 00:03:19.715
on about the loops and swirls.

65
00:03:19.715 --> 00:03:23.067
[LAUGH]
>> I don't know where that came out of,

66
00:03:23.067 --> 00:03:27.460
but [LAUGH] I meant to say homework,
but I guess there's a w in there.

67
00:03:27.460 --> 00:03:28.418
>> Handwriting homework?

68
00:03:28.418 --> 00:03:28.960
>> Yeah.

69
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:30.223
[LAUGH]
>> Trying to help you out.

70
00:03:30.223 --> 00:03:31.019
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

71
00:03:31.019 --> 00:03:35.504
I actually had to have handwriting
homework, because it was so poor.

72
00:03:35.504 --> 00:03:36.076
>> Abysmal?

73
00:03:36.076 --> 00:03:36.852
[LAUGH]
>> Yes,

74
00:03:36.852 --> 00:03:40.760
I got like an N minus when I was in-
>> What the heck is an N minus?

75
00:03:40.760 --> 00:03:43.833
>> [LAUGH] Do you remember
there was SUs and Ns?

76
00:03:43.833 --> 00:03:46.198
>> No, we had As through F.

77
00:03:46.198 --> 00:03:51.579
>> [LAUGH] I guess,
it was a public school in Stewart,

78
00:03:51.579 --> 00:03:55.945
Florida, JD Parker, home of the Cubs.

79
00:03:55.945 --> 00:03:57.657
[LAUGH] I remember that.

80
00:03:57.657 --> 00:04:01.396
Like an O for outstanding,
S for satisfactory, N for

81
00:04:01.396 --> 00:04:04.565
needs improvement, NU is unsatisfactory.

82
00:04:04.565 --> 00:04:07.080
>> Okay,
I do remember that in kindergarten.

83
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:09.784
>> Yeah, well, I guess they were still
doing it when I was in fourth and

84
00:04:09.784 --> 00:04:10.554
five grade [LAUGH].

85
00:04:10.554 --> 00:04:12.796
>> No, that was for the little kids.

86
00:04:12.796 --> 00:04:16.190
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I obviously didn't do very well

87
00:04:16.190 --> 00:04:18.974
in kindergarten handwriting,
because mine is atrocious.

88
00:04:18.974 --> 00:04:23.008
[LAUGH] It was so bad in college, I would
take all the notes, and I'd go back and

89
00:04:23.008 --> 00:04:26.629
read them, and I'd be like,
I can't even read my own handwriting.

90
00:04:26.629 --> 00:04:28.163
Because I'm just like, go, go, go.

91
00:04:28.163 --> 00:04:33.581
So yeah, anyways, I digress yet again,
but we always talk about school.

92
00:04:33.581 --> 00:04:37.826
And this is where, coming back to this,
I remember the teacher's notebook, and

93
00:04:37.826 --> 00:04:41.290
they would sometimes write
diagonally up in the boxes.

94
00:04:41.290 --> 00:04:44.330
Right, because it was a longer title,
but they only had this wide, so

95
00:04:44.330 --> 00:04:45.910
they would kinda angle it up.

96
00:04:45.910 --> 00:04:50.220
So that's the whole idea of where
I'm coming back with this story of

97
00:04:50.220 --> 00:04:53.520
selecting our cells, and
now look, it's just easy.

98
00:04:53.520 --> 00:04:57.750
You just click a button and
go to the angular clockwise and boop.

99
00:04:57.750 --> 00:04:58.680
>> Super sweet.

100
00:04:58.680 --> 00:05:00.749
>> Look at that, so pretty easy to do.

101
00:05:00.749 --> 00:05:01.690
>> It's like a ledger.

102
00:05:01.690 --> 00:05:02.500
>> Yeah.

103
00:05:02.500 --> 00:05:03.606
>> Yeah, ledgers do that, don't they?

104
00:05:03.606 --> 00:05:04.440
Yeah.

105
00:05:04.440 --> 00:05:06.746
>> Gradebooks, right, you have to go up.

106
00:05:06.746 --> 00:05:10.198
And that's where if you did
have a really small column,

107
00:05:10.198 --> 00:05:14.914
cuz maybe you only have values that
are a couple numbers, like test values.

108
00:05:14.914 --> 00:05:17.340
But you wanna set it like test one,
test two, test three.

109
00:05:17.340 --> 00:05:19.274
And you wanna keep those columns small.

110
00:05:19.274 --> 00:05:23.830
You could select those cells, and then you
could just go ahead and go all the way up.

111
00:05:23.830 --> 00:05:26.893
You can rotate the text up, so
you can go ahead and put it that way.

112
00:05:26.893 --> 00:05:32.148
So pretty easy to do now in Excel, just
go ahead and selecting and changing it.

113
00:05:32.148 --> 00:05:36.618
But just like our bolds or anything else
that you have like a button that turns on

114
00:05:36.618 --> 00:05:39.867
and off, this is back to that
whole where can I go ahead and

115
00:05:39.867 --> 00:05:43.105
get the just regular
horizontal text button?

116
00:05:43.105 --> 00:05:45.647
Nope, you just turn the vertical off,

117
00:05:45.647 --> 00:05:49.360
you turn the rotation off from
this drop down right here.

118
00:05:49.360 --> 00:05:53.480
And then it goes back down
to being regular across.

119
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:58.270
Now, those are some pretty easy ones,
there's a 45 and a 90 degree angle there.

120
00:05:58.270 --> 00:06:02.620
But if you wanted, let's say,
a 62 degree angle in there,

121
00:06:02.620 --> 00:06:05.830
you can go into
the Format Cells Alignment,

122

Another way to think about it is

you could if you wanted to go into
those options, so storing as text.

And the one that I wanted to show you

I wanna be able to type in 98 degrees, or

98 and
it puts a little degree sign on there.

383
00:20:04.350 --> 00:20:06.075
>> Right.
>> If you need extra characters,

384
00:20:06.075 --> 00:20:07.630
those special characters.

00:20:07.630 --> 00:20:11.100
This is how I would say the easiest
way is to do it, if I type in 98.

00:20:11.100 --> 00:20:14.250
Now where do I go for a special character.

387
00:20:14.250 --> 00:20:20.060
This is just like in Word, you go over
into Insert and there is symbols.

388
00:20:20.060 --> 00:20:22.950
Now notice I still have my flashing
cursor in the place where I

389
00:20:22.950 --> 00:20:28.040
want to have that degree
sign to be Inputted.

390
00:20:28.040 --> 00:20:30.060
So you come over to insert,
you go to symbol.

391
00:20:30.060 --> 00:20:35.030
And then in here you now need to find that

00:20:35.030 --> 00:20:38.290
particular special character
that you want to insert.

00:20:39.560 --> 00:20:41.840
This is our font, normal text.

394
00:20:41.840 --> 00:20:44.219
If this goes in into windings or

00:20:44.219 --> 00:20:49.434
something like that make sure you
just kinda go back up into normal,

00:20:49.434 --> 00:20:55.214
cuz that's gonna give you the blankest
[LAUGH] character set, most blank.

397
00:20:55.214 --> 00:20:57.375
[LAUGH] Yeah, okay, there we go.

398
00:20:57.375 --> 00:20:58.455
[LAUGH]
>> And Vonne, let me clarify,

00:20:58.455 --> 00:21:00.395

>> Yes, well that would be another font.

00:21:02.905 --> 00:21:05.245

402
00:21:05.245 --> 00:21:06.315
>> Right, right, right.

403
00:21:06.315 --> 00:21:10.765
>> So I need to find the degree sign,
I think I already passed it.

00:21:10.765 --> 00:21:13.535
I think it's a little bit further down.

405
00:21:13.535 --> 00:21:15.635
>> I like wingdings it sounds like a-
>> There it is.

406
00:21:15.635 --> 00:21:18.820
So we have here- Where I have
this particular character.

407
00:21:18.820 --> 00:21:23.100
There is a degree sign, so
I need to find that, and then I insert it.

408
00:21:23.100 --> 00:21:26.130
I'm gonna move this dialogue box over so
you can see that when I insert it,

00:21:26.130 --> 00:21:29.780
it actually puts it in to
that text place holder.

00:21:29.780 --> 00:21:31.950
And sometimes people click insert,
insert, insert, and they close, and

00:21:31.950 --> 00:21:33.710
then they have like all these
different degree signs.

00:21:33.710 --> 00:21:34.460
Like, it's doing it.

413
00:21:34.460 --> 00:21:37.592
You just probably have
the dialogue box that's hiding it.

414
00:21:37.592 --> 00:21:42.411
So at 98 degrees, so
I want to be able to type in 102 cause

00:21:42.411 --> 00:21:46.684
that's how it always feels

416
00:21:46.684 --> 00:21:54.100
[LAUGH] so take this, select the text,
and you can copy if you want to.

00:21:55.840 --> 00:21:57.200
Go ahead and then click off of it.

00:21:57.200 --> 00:21:58.530
I would then definitely copy it.

00:21:58.530 --> 00:22:00.010
Sorry let me go ahead and clarify that.

00:22:00.010 --> 00:22:04.740
Go back over to home,

00:22:04.740 --> 00:22:10.900
Come into custom and in that type, get the

00:22:10.900 --> 00:22:14.280
Now you do not want it to show 98 degrees.

423
00:22:14.280 --> 00:22:19.020
But at least you get that
degree symbol in there and

00:22:19.020 --> 00:22:23.060
now you just have to go ahead and

425
00:22:23.060 --> 00:22:27.480
Now could it be zero, it could, right?

426
00:22:27.480 --> 00:22:29.930
Whoops, that's not zero that

00:22:34.420 --> 00:22:37.911
I'm not putting in the number sign,
if I click,

Now if I typed in 120,

431
00:22:48.890 --> 00:22:51.130
But I only put one zero in there.

00:22:51.130 --> 00:22:51.640
That's just so

00:22:51.640 --> 00:22:54.932
if you ever typed in zero it would,
well it didn't recognize it for me.

434
00:22:54.932 --> 00:22:58.750
[LAUGH] It's just that it's
gonna recognize as a character.

435
00:22:58.750 --> 00:23:00.740
So if I typed in 34.

436
00:23:00.740 --> 00:23:01.310
That didn't work.

437
00:23:02.940 --> 00:23:04.460
What didn't that work?

00:23:04.460 --> 00:23:07.580
Hold on, okay, I forgot to go ahead and

00:23:07.580 --> 00:23:11.010

this is perfect, I'm glad I did this.

440
00:23:11.010 --> 00:23:11.630
>> Right, right, right.

441
00:23:11.630 --> 00:23:15.250
>> Didn't plan on it, but-
>> A live debugging moment.

442
00:23:15.250 --> 00:23:18.660
>> We need to make sure
I have this same format

443
00:23:18.660 --> 00:23:21.390
>> For all of these numbers.

444
00:23:21.390 --> 00:23:25.330
I don't wanna copy the number,
I just want the formatting.

445
00:23:25.330 --> 00:23:26.637
Remember, the fill hand though.

446
00:23:26.637 --> 00:23:31.295
The fill hand, it's primary job is to
copy, we use this in the auto fill,

447
00:23:31.295 --> 00:23:33.100
we use it in flash fill.

448
00:23:33.100 --> 00:23:38.197
If I pull this down to let's just
say here for now, don't copy.

449
00:23:38.197 --> 00:23:42.106
Don't copy Just fill in
with the formatting.

450
00:23:42.106 --> 00:23:44.890
>> Yay.
>> Formatting only, there we go.

451
00:23:44.890 --> 00:23:46.760
That's why it wasn't working.

452
00:23:46.760 --> 00:23:52.360
It's now recognizing 0 as a registered
value and it will display that.

453
00:23:52.360 --> 00:23:57.460
It is showing 34, but
I didn't type in 000 because that

454
00:23:57.460 --> 00:24:03.168
way if I typed in 34 it would do what,
034, it would do 098.

455
00:24:03.168 --> 00:24:06.530
Don't need that, so
if you just do the one value.

456
00:24:06.530 --> 00:24:08.921
You can type that in.

457
00:24:08.921 --> 00:24:13.095
I'm using my rounding because if
that's where I need it to go ahead and

458
00:24:13.095 --> 00:24:17.595
get the decimal places to show more and
it didn't do that but that's okay.

459
00:24:17.595 --> 00:24:21.600
[LAUGH] I can go ahead and allow it
to do that, but maybe this is where

460
00:24:21.600 --> 00:24:26.320
sometimes maybe the number format doesn't
always work with every single value.

461
00:24:26.320 --> 00:24:29.320
You gotta be a little careful with some
of these custom number formats, and

462
00:24:29.320 --> 00:24:34.222
think about what your data needs to be and
how to be displayed.

463
00:24:34.222 --> 00:24:37.430
So, it's very handy.

464
00:24:37.430 --> 00:24:41.750
But like with this example where I
said I needed to be 12.6 degrees,

465
00:24:41.750 --> 00:24:46.150
this is where maybe you just go ahead and
forego the degrees sign.

466
00:24:46.150 --> 00:24:51.130
You know that this column is
going to be the temperature and

467
00:24:51.130 --> 00:24:53.320
so, I don't need the symbol.

468
00:24:53.320 --> 00:24:54.840
I need the decimal places.

469
00:24:54.840 --> 00:24:56.770
That's more important.

470
00:24:56.770 --> 00:24:58.620
That's where you could say,
all right, let's go ahead and

471
00:24:58.620 --> 00:25:00.650
change this back to numbers.

472
00:25:00.650 --> 00:25:08.280
I will be able to use those decimal
places because I need it to be 21.6.

473
00:25:08.280 --> 00:25:12.180
And so on and so forth, so
you need to just determine what is more

474
00:25:12.180 --> 00:25:15.920
important to you and that's why
column headings are really great.

475
00:25:15.920 --> 00:25:16.545
>> Fantastic.

476
00:25:16.545 --> 00:25:17.105
>> [CROSSTALK] [INAUDIBLE] symbols.

477
00:25:17.105 --> 00:25:20.960
>> So I think that about covers

478
00:25:20.960 --> 00:25:22.140
You know what?

479

Sorry, one more.

480
00:25:23.130 --> 00:25:24.000
Okay.

481
00:25:24.000 --> 00:25:26.310
Date and time.

482
00:25:26.310 --> 00:25:28.160
>> Yeah.
>> Date and time can be really,

483
00:25:28.160 --> 00:25:30.010
really all over the place.

484
00:25:30.010 --> 00:25:34.320
I do have a website that
gives you a little bit more

485
00:25:34.320 --> 00:25:39.500
information about how to display dates and

486
00:25:39.500 --> 00:25:43.920
times and
what all of these different symbols mean.

487
00:25:43.920 --> 00:25:48.060
Like see right here, like the m's and
the d's and the Hs and

488
00:25:48.060 --> 00:25:51.790
the Y for your hours and minutes.

489
00:25:51.790 --> 00:25:56.350
Time can be one of those things where like
you have to type in like the AM and PM.

490
00:25:56.350 --> 00:26:01.574
Remember because the number
format like if you always want

491
00:26:01.574 --> 00:26:07.570
it to be especially during military time,
23:24.

492
00:26:07.570 --> 00:26:11.230
That is a time.

493
00:26:11.230 --> 00:26:12.980
You can make it custom number format.

494
00:26:12.980 --> 00:26:19.230
You can do 00, open the quote, colon,
close the quote, and then two more zero's.

495
00:26:19.230 --> 00:26:24.535
So that way, you can do 0300 hours,
or 0330, or those types of things.

496
00:26:24.535 --> 00:26:27.380
>> Mm-hm.
>> So you can make your own number format.

497
00:26:27.380 --> 00:26:31.210
But if you're using AM's and
PM's you will have type that in and

498
00:26:31.210 --> 00:26:35.160
that can get a little like
alright I have to go with it.

499
00:26:35.160 --> 00:26:39.050
But this give you a little bit more
information on how you can do that.

500
00:26:39.050 --> 00:26:42.000
You can always make a separate column for
AM and PM.

501
00:26:42.000 --> 00:26:45.760
Like just go ahead then you can't need it,
there's all sorts of different ways you

502
00:26:45.760 --> 00:26:49.930
can do it, but, again, you have to
know what you need your data to show.

503
00:26:49.930 --> 00:26:54.360
Concatenate, by the way, is a function or
a formula that would, then, take this and

504
00:26:54.360 --> 00:26:55.260
this and bring it together.

505
00:26:55.260 --> 00:26:57.210
Or you can do that cool flashville.

506
00:26:57.210 --> 00:27:00.170
Check out the series, or
the episode on flashville cuz that was-

507
00:27:00.170 --> 00:27:00.900
>> Flashville, yeah.

508
00:27:00.900 --> 00:27:01.900
>> That was a lot of fun.

509
00:27:01.900 --> 00:27:05.190
So, and then, of course, creating and
deleting a custom member format,

510
00:27:05.190 --> 00:27:06.940
I wanted to show you the website.

511
00:27:06.940 --> 00:27:09.370
That gives you a little bit
more information about this and

512
00:27:09.370 --> 00:27:13.420
goes a little bit further than
what maybe I have shown you.

513
00:27:13.420 --> 00:27:17.700
That when you get it custom it is custom,
so check this out and

514
00:27:17.700 --> 00:27:20.650
see if you can get your numbers
displaying the way you want them.

515
00:27:20.650 --> 00:27:22.810
And now you know about number formats,

516
00:27:22.810 --> 00:27:27.000
you know why it does it, you know how
to fix it if you need it to be fixed.

517
00:27:27.000 --> 00:27:29.820
And how you can go ahead and
display it, and hopefully,

518
00:27:29.820 --> 00:27:35.520
that D wonkifies our Excel behaviors,
their default behaviors and saying,

519
00:27:35.520 --> 00:27:41.630
I don't want you to do that anymore, so
you have to tell Excel, Do it this way.

520
00:27:42.930 --> 00:27:45.820
>> Excel 2016
Essentials Number Formats Part Two.

521
00:27:45.820 --> 00:27:48.470
There was a Part One, make sure you
see that, you'll be glad you did and

522
00:27:48.470 --> 00:27:52.180

in Excel 2016 Essentials.

523
00:27:52.180 --> 00:27:55.100
And thank you for watching Office Pro TV.

00:27:55.100 --> 00:27:57.230
Remember that a good office

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Justin cover the following number format categories: number, currency, accounting, percentage, fractions, and scientific notation.
episodes.title: Number Formats: Common Number Formats

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin continue with number formats, specifically covering the text, special, and custom categories.
episodes.title: Number Formats: Text, Special, Custom

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne finish the number format mini series by discussing date and time number formats. They also introduce the DATEVALUE function.
episodes.title: Number Formats: Date and Time
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.881 --> 00:00:15.164
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.164 --> 00:00:18.691
I'm your host Justin Dennison and it
looks like you've made it back in time in

4
00:00:18.691 --> 00:00:22.495
order to see our Excel 2016 Essential
series and, well, we're talking about

5
00:00:22.495 --> 00:00:25.950

we're talking about dates and times.

6
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:28.322
If you haven't watched
the previous episode,

7
00:00:28.322 --> 00:00:31.117
go see the nice little
foreshadowing that I left there.

8
00:00:31.117 --> 00:00:35.812
And, well, luckily we have someone who can
bend space-time with her will to tell us

9
00:00:35.812 --> 00:00:37.677
all about them, Ms Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:37.677 --> 00:00:39.979
How are you doing today, Vonne?
>> Well, I didn't know I had that special

11
00:00:39.979 --> 00:00:42.170
power [LAUGH].
>> I might have over-promised on that one

12
00:00:42.170 --> 00:00:44.345
a little bit but
we'll go with it this time, right?

13
00:00:44.345 --> 00:00:47.025
So dates and times,
it seems pretty simple but

14
00:00:47.025 --> 00:00:51.358
I know from my experience they're not
always as simple as they first appear

15
00:00:51.358 --> 00:00:53.480
to be.
>> No, they are not.

16
00:00:53.480 --> 00:00:54.795
>> And there's so

17
00:00:54.795 --> 00:01:00.369
many different ways to do dates,
it's kinda scary a little bit.

18
00:01:00.369 --> 00:01:04.382
And then you go down the rabbit hole of
all the different ways of going ahead and

19
00:01:04.382 --> 00:01:05.444
displaying dates.

20
00:01:05.444 --> 00:01:10.040
It can be a little scary, so
I'd like to start there actually with

21
00:01:10.040 --> 00:01:14.570
a little bit of trivial knowledge or
I don't know about trivia.

22
00:01:14.570 --> 00:01:17.475
But let's go to the computer and
see what we got down in here,

23
00:01:17.475 --> 00:01:22.730
I've got a couple of websites
pulled up and, of course, you

24
00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:26.260
can't not go to Wikipedia, I think that's
a double negative somewhere in there.

25
00:01:26.260 --> 00:01:29.052
I think it is.
>> But I think it's allowed if you can't

26
00:01:29.052 --> 00:01:31.412
not do something, right?
>> Yeah.

27
00:01:31.412 --> 00:01:34.842
>> I think that's an acceptable double

28
00:01:34.842 --> 00:01:38.193
negative in that context.
>> Okay, I buy it.

29
00:01:38.193 --> 00:01:40.105
>> It's not like I'm saying,

30
00:01:40.105 --> 00:01:43.697
I'm not hardly hoping not to or
something like that.

31
00:01:43.697 --> 00:01:47.010
[LAUGH] It's not something like that,
I can't not go to, so.

32
00:01:47.010 --> 00:01:49.380
>> Good, I like it and I use it a lot.

33
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:53.900
So yes, we have date and
time notation in the United States.

34
00:01:53.900 --> 00:01:59.130
And we're pretty much different from
any other English speaking country.

35
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:03.401
It's like we're just different,
we always need to be, just because.

36
00:02:03.401 --> 00:02:08.228
And you could see that if I was
going to say, what is today, Justin,

37
00:02:08.228 --> 00:02:12.476
what would you say?
>> I would say 3/14/18 or

38
00:02:12.476 --> 00:02:18.408
3/14/2018 or
sometimes I have seen padded with 0s.

39
00:02:18.408 --> 00:02:23.716
I tend to go with the less
ambiguous approach like four years.

40
00:02:23.716 --> 00:02:26.593
But that's based on my background and
things that I've done.

41
00:02:26.593 --> 00:02:29.054
>> Yeah and if it's March 14,

42
00:02:29.054 --> 00:02:34.477
2018 we say the month,
then the day, then the year, right?

43
00:02:34.477 --> 00:02:40.576
But we could say it's the 14th
of March in the year of 2018.

44
00:02:40.576 --> 00:02:42.490
That's totally valid, too.

45
00:02:43.950 --> 00:02:48.670
We usually use a 12 hour clock notation.

46
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:51.895
The military time which I have to
sit there and add on my fingers or

47
00:02:51.895 --> 00:02:55.801
subtract every time cuz it's just
a little, they're like, it's so easy.

48
00:02:55.801 --> 00:02:59.336
I'm like yeah,
if you get used to it and that's fine.

49
00:02:59.336 --> 00:03:03.143
But there's just different
ways that you can go ahead and

50
00:03:03.143 --> 00:03:07.189
designate the years and
all about whether there's a slash,

51
00:03:07.189 --> 00:03:11.567
is there a hyphen, is there a period,
which one is it going to be?

52
00:03:11.567 --> 00:03:16.143
And then it also talks about that we do,
usually spoken with

53
00:03:16.143 --> 00:03:20.914
the year as a cardinal number and
the day as an ordinal number.

54
00:03:20.914 --> 00:03:24.229
So do you know the difference
between cardinal and ordinal,

55
00:03:24.229 --> 00:03:26.808
Justin?
>> Ordinal is for ordering,

56
00:03:26.808 --> 00:03:32.046
like the first, the second, the third and
cardinal is how we typically say numbers.

57
00:03:32.046 --> 00:03:35.496
Like, that's 2009 or whatever it may be.
>> Yeah, so

58
00:03:35.496 --> 00:03:37.730
I think they say here, quantity.

59
00:03:37.730 --> 00:03:38.267
Yes.
And

60
00:03:38.267 --> 00:03:42.050
I think it's ordinals that
are actually something within fonts,

61
00:03:42.050 --> 00:03:46.250
like in font sets and
how it's actually represented,

62
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:50.990
how they do the superscript of those
particular characters, it's kind of fun.

63
00:03:50.990 --> 00:03:52.152
And I love to talk about it,

64
00:03:52.152 --> 00:03:56.630
yeah, cuz you have things in your
font sets like swashes and ordinals.

65
00:03:56.630 --> 00:03:58.850
And people will go what?

66
00:03:58.850 --> 00:03:59.950
And I'm like it's fun.

67
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:00.895
And glyphs?

68
00:04:00.895 --> 00:04:02.043
Gotta love a glyph.

69
00:04:02.043 --> 00:04:04.915
So anyways,
we've got those different things and

70
00:04:04.915 --> 00:04:08.853
I do think it was kinda fun to talk
about all the different countries and

71
00:04:08.853 --> 00:04:13.258
what type of things and then how we're
right over here in the big old fuchsia but

72
00:04:13.258 --> 00:04:15.966
Canada is hanging out there by itself too,

This is the problem with data period,
it's hard to trust sometimes and

533
00:30:01.812 --> 00:30:06.436
just letting our computers
just do what it's gonna do.

534
00:30:06.436 --> 00:30:09.443
You still need to have a little
bit of a human component.

535
00:30:09.443 --> 00:30:13.221
But getting into that metaphysical area,
where it's like we need to go, we need to,

536
00:30:13.221 --> 00:30:14.069
back up, back up.

537
00:30:14.069 --> 00:30:15.437
[LAUGH]
>> Well Vonne,

538
00:30:15.437 --> 00:30:19.650
I can definitely see that we need to go
before we dive too deep into the weeds.

539
00:30:19.650 --> 00:30:21.140
We're about right here.

540
00:30:21.140 --> 00:30:23.110
I'm starting to have
a hard time breathing.

541
00:30:23.110 --> 00:30:24.270
But you're absolutely correct.

542
00:30:24.270 --> 00:30:28.287
Data is dirty, and it needs a little
bit of human touch to clean it up.

543
00:30:28.287 --> 00:30:32.388
So do keep these in mind as you're kind
of manipulating dates and numbers.

544
00:30:32.388 --> 00:30:37.130
And I think this actually concludes our
mini series on various number formats.

545
00:30:37.130 --> 00:30:41.580
We dove deep into a few of those, and
that's to help you not be frustrated and

546
00:30:41.580 --> 00:30:42.920
become more productive.

547
00:30:42.920 --> 00:30:45.450
So definitely come on back,
we got more coming at you.

548
00:30:45.450 --> 00:30:47.320
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

549
00:30:47.320 --> 00:30:50.180
Signing out for Office Pro TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

550
00:30:50.180 --> 00:30:50.916
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

551
00:30:50.916 --> 00:30:51.759
>> And we'll see you next time.

552
00:30:51.759 --> 00:30:58.223
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Vonne demonstrate how to proof and control page layout for printing. They show how to spellcheck a worksheet and the options for ignoring or adding to the dictionary as well as how to use the thesaurus and smart lookup.  They also show how to modify page layout from print preview in the backstage view.
episodes.title: Proof, Print and Page Layout

WEBVTT

00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:13.980

00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:27.330
Did the same thing I'm like,

I'm hypothesizing that it

00:09:38.085 --> 00:09:43.730
So this might be a me thing,

00:10:04.430 --> 00:10:07.360

00:10:07.360 --> 00:10:09.930

everything around.

423
00:23:15.064 --> 00:23:18.100
And you can change your center, on the
page, which is kind of a big thing for me.

424
00:23:18.100 --> 00:23:20.650
I kinda like to have things
vertically centered a lot of times.

425
00:23:20.650 --> 00:23:22.630
So I if I choose that vertically centered,

426
00:23:22.630 --> 00:23:27.510
notice that it's gonna jump down into
the vertical center of the page.

427
00:23:27.510 --> 00:23:30.680
And that’s where my margins,
really the left and

428
00:23:30.680 --> 00:23:33.910
right margins are going to be the biggest
part that I need to worry about.

429
00:23:33.910 --> 00:23:39.602
All right, so headers and footers, we can
still do this from this print preview and

430
00:23:39.602 --> 00:23:44.094
this backstage view, but
you just don't have a dropdown for it.

431
00:23:44.094 --> 00:23:49.298
But you do have that dialogue box in
the page setup to where you can come

432
00:23:49.298 --> 00:23:54.251
into our header and footer, now,
what are headers and footers?

433
00:23:54.251 --> 00:23:58.263
They're things that go on the top of
the page, and the things that go on

434
00:23:58.263 --> 00:24:02.151
the bottom of the page, and
they will repeat on every printed page.

435
00:24:02.151 --> 00:24:07.693
So if I had six pages, It's gonna
print on all six of those pages.

436
00:24:07.693 --> 00:24:12.289
But one thing from doing it from this
particular dialog box is you don't

437
00:24:12.289 --> 00:24:15.280
really see it until you click OK.

438
00:24:15.280 --> 00:24:20.810
So you kinda have to do it, click OK
if you wanna preview it right here,

439
00:24:20.810 --> 00:24:23.150
then come back into the dialog box and
keep on going.

440
00:24:24.250 --> 00:24:29.190
Now, the headers and footers,
you have three specific areas.

441
00:24:29.190 --> 00:24:32.680
You have the left,
the center, and the right.

442
00:24:32.680 --> 00:24:35.270
In Word, we talked about these
with tab stops and everything, but

443
00:24:35.270 --> 00:24:37.340
since we're not in Word, you're like,
I don't care what's in Word.

444
00:24:37.340 --> 00:24:39.260
Well, I mean, not that you don't care.

445
00:24:39.260 --> 00:24:43.360
But I'm just trying to correlate to
something you might have already done.

446
00:24:43.360 --> 00:24:46.850
You don't have to worry about tab stops
here cuz they actually compartmentalize

447
00:24:46.850 --> 00:24:47.760
it for you.

448
00:24:47.760 --> 00:24:52.960
Watch, maybe I want to have on my header,
I clicked on the custom header button,

449
00:24:52.960 --> 00:25:00.240
I would like to have my name,
the date, and the file name.

450
00:25:00.240 --> 00:25:01.450
Cuz that's would I need to have.

451
00:25:01.450 --> 00:25:04.450
This is something that maybe in
you're particular organizations,

452
00:25:04.450 --> 00:25:06.450
it's like you always need to
put the file path in there,

453
00:25:06.450 --> 00:25:09.210
you always need to put the date when
you're printing on something because

454
00:25:09.210 --> 00:25:12.440
this is just like for
the record that you need to know that

455
00:25:12.440 --> 00:25:16.890
anybody that sees this needs to know
when it was done and where it came from.

456
00:25:16.890 --> 00:25:21.110
Luckily, you don't have to type that
out because those are things like

457
00:25:21.110 --> 00:25:26.060
properties of either the document or
Just the day that happens.

458
00:25:26.060 --> 00:25:28.990
So if I have my flashing
cursor over here on left, see?

459
00:25:28.990 --> 00:25:29.820
No tab stops.

460
00:25:29.820 --> 00:25:32.940
I can just type in Vonne Smith.

00:25:32.940 --> 00:25:34.680
And I will click in the center.

462
00:25:34.680 --> 00:25:40.110
I want the date, but
I want it to change when the date changes.

463
00:25:40.110 --> 00:25:42.610
If this was for tomorrow,
then it would change there.

464
00:25:42.610 --> 00:25:48.430
Notice you do have some buttons across the
top of what I can choose to put in there.

465
00:25:48.430 --> 00:25:52.409
So you click your cursor in the section
that you want to be in, and

466
00:25:52.409 --> 00:25:57.716

file name, sheet name, all sorts of neat

468
00:26:02.535 --> 00:26:04.030
I'm gonna choose insert date.

469
00:26:05.080 --> 00:26:08.900
It doesn't save the day, it's just
putting it in that special code that it

00:26:08.900 --> 00:26:11.890

the day is right now.

471
00:26:11.890 --> 00:26:15.010
I go to the right, it's kinda hard

00:26:15.010 --> 00:26:17.350
cause it's gonna be right justified.

473
00:26:17.350 --> 00:26:21.895
Let's put in that file path and

474
00:26:21.895 --> 00:26:26.560
And you can see from the page setup
that that is kind of what it's.

475
00:26:26.560 --> 00:26:28.280
It's kind of like moving all together.

476
00:26:28.280 --> 00:26:28.930
That's okay.

477
00:26:28.930 --> 00:26:32.180
Click OK here, and then let's scroll out.

478
00:26:32.180 --> 00:26:32.780
See?

479
00:26:32.780 --> 00:26:35.000
It does come in to the right sections.

480
00:26:35.000 --> 00:26:36.832
It's not gonna overlap itself.

481
00:26:36.832 --> 00:26:42.160
It was just in that particular dialog box
that it wasn't able to see everything.

482
00:26:42.160 --> 00:26:43.120
So, awesome.

483
00:26:43.120 --> 00:26:44.200
We can put that to the top.

484
00:26:44.200 --> 00:26:46.740
Let's go back down to that footer.

485
00:26:46.740 --> 00:26:48.890
Come back in to our page setup.

486
00:26:48.890 --> 00:26:50.700
We go over to Headers and Footers.

487
00:26:50.700 --> 00:26:52.130
In this sense,
I only want the page numbers.

488
00:26:52.130 --> 00:26:53.790
I don't wanna put anything else special.

489
00:26:53.790 --> 00:26:56.493
I don't need to occupy the three spaces.

490
00:26:56.493 --> 00:27:00.090
Notice that in both the header and

491
00:27:00.090 --> 00:27:04.070
And in this drop-down, it can choose,

492

And it's got some ones that like see,
there's Page, that's the file name,

493
00:27:08.000 --> 00:27:09.640
there's the file path.

494
00:27:09.640 --> 00:27:11.130
Weekly Sales Page 1.

495
00:27:11.130 --> 00:27:14.050
So it's giving you some default
ones that maybe you're like,

00:27:14.050 --> 00:27:15.240
that's exactly what I need.

497
00:27:15.240 --> 00:27:18.805
I need the username,
what page I'm on, and the date.

498
00:27:18.805 --> 00:27:20.480
So you can choose it from the drop-down.

499
00:27:20.480 --> 00:27:23.379
You don't always have to go under

500
00:27:23.379 --> 00:27:27.928
And so for example on this one,
I would like to just do page one of, and

501
00:27:27.928 --> 00:27:29.897
then however many they have.

502
00:27:29.897 --> 00:27:33.227
And I click that,
drop that down, click OK, boop,

00:27:33.227 --> 00:27:37.264
there it is it's right on down
there that I have page one of one.

504
00:27:37.264 --> 00:27:40.965
Now I only have one page so
that's all I've got but

505
00:27:40.965 --> 00:27:46.621
if you had more then it would go ahead and
print on every single printed page.

506
00:27:46.621 --> 00:27:47.280
>> Fantastic.

507
00:27:47.280 --> 00:27:48.006
>> Very nice.
>> Yes.

508
00:27:48.006 --> 00:27:51.712
>> And those are all the things that we

00:27:51.712 --> 00:27:54.620
box, or

But the page setup is the dialog box.

But, there's some other things that I

And then we also have the really

00:28:19.070 --> 00:28:21.200
Proof, print, page layout, part one.

There will be a part two,

And make sure you watch every single video

Great job.

And remember,

526

episodes.description:
"
Vonne and Zach continue discussing page layout. In this episode, they show how to modify page layout elements from the page layout view such as headers and footers, page orientation, and margins. They also go over adding print titles, setting a print area, and controlling page breaks."
episodes.title: Proof, Print and Page Layout Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne finish up the Excel 2016 Essentials series by demonstrating how to manage workbooks and worksheets. Here they show you how to rename worksheet tabs, change tab color, rearrange worksheets, create new and delete worksheets, and copy/hide/move worksheets. They also show how to control view options such as freeze panes, split view, new windows, and arranging windows.
episodes.title: Manage Sheets and Workbooks
